THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, OCTOBER 21, 1930

DR. AMES NOT TO
LECTURE THURSDAY
Dr. Ames has announced
that due to his absence from
the city, he will be unable to
give his regular weekly lecture on October 23, to his
class of undergraduates at
10.30 A. M.
—o—
NOTICE
"Leadership" will be the
topic of the address to be delivered by Arthur D. Little,
November 7, in Remsen Hall,
Room 1, at 8 P. M., it was
learned from Dr. Neil E. Gordon, of the Chemistry Department last Saturday.
The sound picture of Dr.
Robert Millikan's speech,
"Cosmic Rays," will be presented also. The public is invited to attend.

Johns College
For the Assembly this coming
Thursday, the Student Council, and
particularly Francis Warlow, the
president of that organization, has
made arrangements to procure a
most eminent speaker, a man whose
name will always be a by-word with
Colonial art and architecture. Not
only for his immense knowledge but
his imposing personality has made
him an outstanding exponent of this
particular period of American civilization.
Dr. R. T. H. Halsey, a resident
of Annapolis and a professor of art
at the St. Johns College, is the
speaker. In accordance with his
profession, even his own home in
Annapolis, the Bordley - Randall
House, is finished in the style of
our forefathers. It is an impressive
mansion, pointed out by Annapolitans as a landmark in the quaint
city, and a visitor is hardly appreciative of the beauties of the place
unless he has seen this house. Indeed, it is very fortunate that the
services of such a distinguished and
cultured gentleman as Dr. Halsey
could be acquired. He will be long
remembered by not only the alumni
of St. Johns for his unique and
comprehensive course in the study
of Colonial times, but also by the
countless numbers who have heard
him lecture before.
The lecture N(rill be divided into
two parts, one of which is entitled
"Charles Carroll of Carrollton, the
Builder of Homewood," and a
second part which will treat of the
Annapolis of old. The lecture will
be augmented by slides which, because of their scarcity in other
assemblies, should tend to interest
the undergraduate body to a higher
degree than an unillustrated talk.

At a meeting of the American
College of Surgeons held in Philadelphia on Wednesday, October 15,
Dr. Howard A. Kelly, a distinguished surgeon of this city, related some of the features of
electro-surgery. He claimed that
electro-surgery is as far in advance
of scalpel surgery as the electric
tram is ahead of the lumbering old
horse car.
An operation by electro-surgery
is almost never halted because of
hemorrhage, he said, the tissues
being sterilized, diseased tissues destroyed and post-operative pain reduced, all in one operation.
"Innumerable face operations are
being undertaken by electro-surgery
which we would not have thought
of undertaking in general surgery,"
he said. "Electro-surgery is a new
and potent help to the surgeon. It
does many things better,some things
that hitherto were impossible, and
all with a lessening of post-operative
pain."
He also asserted that the new
technique permits the extension of
surgery of the brain into new fields
and delicate areas hitherto untouched. It opens up the possibility
of greatly extending the application
of surgical measures to the spinal
cord.
The electric knife is a needle-like
affair with alternating current of
high frequency. It burns rather
than cuts its way through the tissue.
For some time the College of
Surgeons has been conducting investigations into its possibilities.

Rutgers Conquers 33-0
SOPHS PLAN TO HOLD
ELECTION TOMORROW
At a meeting of the Sophomore Class on Friday, October 17, in Room 120 of the
Civil Engineering Building,
the following menwere nominated for office.
President — Lyons, Turnbull and Rome.
Secretary—W oodrow,
Edgerton and Hughes.
Treasurer—Dolowitz, Henderson, Frey, Cockey, Kahl,
Hanpart and Weller.
Sergeant-atArms — Davis,
Badanes, Gordon, Di Genaro
and Gilbert.
The election will be held
tomorrow (Wednesday, October 21, at 12.30, in Room
120 of the Civil Engineering
Building. Nominations may
also be renewed at this meeting. All Sophomores are
urged to attend.

Lacrosse Season Outlook
Bright; Schedule Heavy
Prospects for another winning
lacrosse team look good again this
year. Seven regular defense men—
Capt. Joe Bernard; Frank Cone,
the only Senior on the team; Rowland Ness, Ronald Levy, Jimmy
McCabe, George Hudert and Bill
Weitzel—and nine regular attack
men,including Jack Turnbull,Lorne
Guild, Bill Triplett, George Packard, Douglas Stone,

Outweighed Hopkins Squad
Unable To Withstand
Attacks
EFFORT TO SCORE IN
THIRD PERIOD FUTILE
Repeated Onslaughts of Hopkins Rebuffed
With a 200-pound fullback leading the way, Rutgers College scored
four touchdowns in the first half
and defeated the Hopkins gridders,
33 to 0, at New Brunswick last Saturday. Jack Grossman, the New
Jersey fullback, led the scoring as
four of the five touchdowns were
made by him.
Hopkins, outweighed ten pounds
to the man, was unable to penetrate
the Rutgers defense while the line
would not consistently stop their
powerful offense. In the third quarter the Jays kept the victors from
scoring but early in the fourth
period they scored again.
Bauer kicked off to Waldron to
start the game. Taking the ball on
his goal line the Scarlet quarterback
returned it 47 yards. Three first
downs followed in which the lighter
Hopkins team could not withstand
the speed and power of the home
team. At the goal line the Black
and Blue eleven held for three
downs only to have Dunlap score
on the fourth. Before the period
ended Grossman, aided by a 15-yard
penalty inflicted on the Hopkins
team, scored his first touchdown.
Harris added the extra point.

Honorary
of
Degree
At the sixty-sixth convention of
the University of the State of New
York, Dr. William Henry Welch
received the honorary degree of
doctor of laws.
Doctor Welch, who is professor
of the history of medicine at the
Johns Hopkins Medical School, has
done much to make available to the
public the benefits of scientific
medicine.
In conferring the degree, Dr.
Frank Groves, president of the university, said:
"As a pioneer, you have blazed
a trail leading from the discoveries
of Pasteur and Koch to the wonders
of pathology and bacteriology
demonstrated through the great hospitals and research laboratories of
today."

Glee Club Rehearses
First Time at Y. M.C. A.
Tryouts having been conducted
during the past week, the Johns
Hopkins Glee Club, under the direction of Mr. Steinwald, held its
first rehearsal in Levering Hall on
Thursday evening, October 16. According to Bruce Peake, president
of the Musical Club, prospects for
the corning season are very birght.
There has been an especially large
turnout for the Glee Club this year
and the group is of a very promising nature. At the present time the
organization is rehearsing "The
Song of the Jolly Roger," a lively
tune of the sea. The vocalists are
very enthusiastic over this number,
for it is a truly virile piece of music.
Although no definite plans have
been made, the club will probably
start rehearsal on a spiritual number in the near future. Frequent
recitals will be held throughout the
year, and several trips have been
scheduled. The Blue Jay Orchestra
rehearsed on Thursday afternoon
and, according to Bert Clark, the
leader, there are a few positions
still available to candidates.

and Sonny Kneip, have returned to
the University. Several Freshmen
have shown very promising work,
especially Don Kelly, from Friends
School, who was seen with the
Olympics last year, and Millard
Lang, the brother of Johnny Lang,
erstwhile Jay star. The loss of a
goalkeeper will be keenly felt, both
Corner Brownley and Joe Ferrarini
having graduated. Gene Lyons and
Sam Dell will try to fill this vacancy.
The Hopkins team opens the season on March 28 against the Olympics. On April 4 they will meet
Yale; April 11, Swarthmore; the
next week, Virginia. On April 25
they play Mt. \Vashington ; on May
1, Princeton, and May 2, St. Johns;
May 9, Syracuse, and Army on
May 16. • The season will be concluded on May 23 when the Jays
play Maryland.
Last year Hopkins lost only one
league game, finishing in a triple tie
for first place. It is expected that
this year the team will be better
than ever. However, they face a
very hard schedule of ten games.
On May 1 the team travels to
Princeton and the following day
they face St. Johns at home. Only
a super-team can face this with
hopes of victory, but the prospects
of victories are very bright.
Candidates are asked to be
present at practices every Tuesday
and Friday afternoon. The importance of Fall practice cannot be
over-emphasized. Candidates for
Freshman managership are asked to
report to Manager L. A. McNeer at
the field on Tuesdays and Fridays.

Cotillion Board Plans
Dance This Saturday
The fourth dance to be sponsored
by the Johns Hopkins Cotillion
Board this year is scheduled for
next Saturday, October 25, in
Levering Hall. Bob Iula's Orchestra will furnish the music.

Makes 60-Yard Dash

Shortly after the kick-off the big
back again rang up the bell when he
went through center and down the
field to cross the goal line which
was 60 yards from where he started.
This time the try for the extra point
failed. Then it was that the Jays
rallied and for a time it seemed possible that a Black and Blue score
might result. Lang recovered a
punt by Turnbull that had touched
a Rutgers' player. A seven-yard
gain by Bobby Lyons and a fiveyard penalty for Rutgers combined
to give Hopkins a first down but
the rally was stopped as Lyons was
thrown for a 16-yard loss. However, the Jays were not yet stopped.
Standing on his 30-yard line Turnbull passed to Lyons for a gain of
20 yards. This was followed by
another gain of 14 yards by the
same men. A third forward pass
was intercepted near the goal line
just as the half ended.
Reach 40-Yard Line

against them, the Hopkins gridders
continued to battle the Scarlet team
and even advanced as far as Rutgers' 40-yard line. Here the home
team held for downs and then began
a march of 80 yards that resulted
in the final score. Grossman, Drake

Harold Bloom has apparently
handled the issue capably. But by
the very nature of the Jay his labor
is confined to the separation of the
terrible copy from the worse. Certainly his first issue of last year was
definitely an improvement on those
edited by his predecessor. But the
current issue is something that
should be remembered along with
last year's football team and the notorious Y. M. C. A. prohibition conference. In his manifesto, Mr.
Bloom urges his readers to reciprocate the attitude of tolerance that
the Jay maintains toward them.
Personally, I think he should have
asked for mercy.

A number of freshmen have come
out for the team. Rappaport,
Sneeringer, and Strong look the best
among the first-year men. Although
there will be a frosh team these men
probably will make the varsity. This
will leave a few vacancies on the
freshman team. An interesting
schedule is being prepared for the
yearlings. Meets are being booked
with Tome School, Maryland frosh
and the freshmen teams of St.
Johns and Gettysburg. All those
who wish to tiy out for the team
should report to the coach at 4
o'clock any day this week.
There will also be a freshmansophomore meet tomorrow. The
race will be over a two-and-a-half
mile course. All those who care to
compete should come tomorrow afternoon to the football field.

RICES should be lower at the Levering Hall cafeteria than in any
other cafeteria in the city. However, this does not seem to be the
case. Many students find that they receive more for their money in
other places, and hence refuse to patronize the local restaurant. The
cafeteria at Levering Hall is not supposed to make a profit. It is intended that enough be made to pay for the upkeep and a small rent.
Other cafeterias have an overhead which is higher than this rent and
upkeep, and must also make a profit. Something is wrong with the local
cafeteria. Either the management is poor or more money is being
made than Y. M. C. A. originally planned. In either case a change
should take place.
Last year many experiments had to be made. Innovations were
frequent, and profits were few. The problem of a rush at twelve
twenty was met and solved as well as possible. New situations constantly came up. By now the institution should be stabilized. The
period of experimentation should have come to an end. Definite
figures as to how many people eat at each meal are at hand. It should
be relatively easy to determine what profits will be and what prices
should be charged.
We hear the situation is being investigated and that an early
change may be anticipated. If such a decrease does not soon take
place, serious and just criticism will certainly result, and the cafeteria
may expect a lean future.

DR. AMES NOT TO
LECTURE THURSDAY
Dr. Ames has announced
that due to his absence from
the city, he will be unable to
give his regular weekly lecture on October 23, to his
class of undergraduates at
10.30 A. M.
—o—
NOTICE
"Leadership" will be the
topic of the address to be delivered by Arthur D. Little,
November 7, in Remsen Hall,
Room 1, at 8 P. M., it was
learned from Dr. Neil E. Gordon, of the Chemistry Department last Saturday.
The sound picture of Dr.
Robert Millikan's speech,
"Cosmic Rays," will be presented also. The public is invited to attend.

Johns College
For the Assembly this coming
Thursday, the Student Council, and
particularly Francis Warlow, the
president of that organization, has
made arrangements to procure a
most eminent speaker, a man whose
name will always be a by-word with
Colonial art and architecture. Not
only for his immense knowledge but
his imposing personality has made
him an outstanding exponent of this
particular period of American civilization.
Dr. R. T. H. Halsey, a resident
of Annapolis and a professor of art
at the St. Johns College, is the
speaker. In accordance with his
profession, even his own home in
Annapolis, the Bordley - Randall
House, is finished in the style of
our forefathers. It is an impressive
mansion, pointed out by Annapolitans as a landmark in the quaint
city, and a visitor is hardly appreciative of the beauties of the place
unless he has seen this house. Indeed, it is very fortunate that the
services of such a distinguished and
cultured gentleman as Dr. Halsey
could be acquired. He will be long
remembered by not only the alumni
of St. Johns for his unique and
comprehensive course in the study
of Colonial times, but also by the
countless numbers who have heard
him lecture before.
The lecture N(rill be divided into
two parts, one of which is entitled
"Charles Carroll of Carrollton, the
Builder of Homewood," and a
second part which will treat of the
Annapolis of old. The lecture will
be augmented by slides which, because of their scarcity in other
assemblies, should tend to interest
the undergraduate body to a higher
degree than an unillustrated talk.

At a meeting of the American
College of Surgeons held in Philadelphia on Wednesday, October 15,
Dr. Howard A. Kelly, a distinguished surgeon of this city, related some of the features of
electro-surgery. He claimed that
electro-surgery is as far in advance
of scalpel surgery as the electric
tram is ahead of the lumbering old
horse car.
An operation by electro-surgery
is almost never halted because of
hemorrhage, he said, the tissues
being sterilized, diseased tissues destroyed and post-operative pain reduced, all in one operation.
"Innumerable face operations are
being undertaken by electro-surgery
which we would not have thought
of undertaking in general surgery,"
he said. "Electro-surgery is a new
and potent help to the surgeon. It
does many things better,some things
that hitherto were impossible, and
all with a lessening of post-operative
pain."
He also asserted that the new
technique permits the extension of
surgery of the brain into new fields
and delicate areas hitherto untouched. It opens up the possibility
of greatly extending the application
of surgical measures to the spinal
cord.
The electric knife is a needle-like
affair with alternating current of
high frequency. It burns rather
than cuts its way through the tissue.
For some time the College of
Surgeons has been conducting investigations into its possibilities.

With a 200-pound fullback leading the way, Rutgers College scored
four touchdowns in the first half
and defeated the Hopkins gridders,
33 to 0, at New Brunswick last Saturday. Jack Grossman, the New
Jersey fullback, led the scoring as
four of the five touchdowns were
made by him.
Hopkins, outweighed ten pounds
to the man, was unable to penetrate
the Rutgers defense while the line
would not consistently stop their
powerful offense. In the third quarter the Jays kept the victors from

period they scored again.
Bauer kicked off to Waldron to

returned it 47 yards. Three first

Hopkins team could not withstand
the speed and power of the home
team. At the goal line the Black
and Blue eleven held for three

on the fourth. Before the period

penalty inflicted on the Hopkins

Degree
At the sixty-sixth convention of
the University of the State of New
York, Dr. William Henry Welch
received the honorary degree of
doctor of laws.
Doctor Welch, who is professor
of the history of medicine at the
Johns Hopkins Medical School, has
done much to make available to the
public the benefits of scientific
medicine.
In conferring the degree, Dr.
Frank Groves, president of the university, said:
"As a pioneer, you have blazed
a trail leading from the discoveries
of Pasteur and Koch to the wonders
of pathology and bacteriology
demonstrated through the great hospitals and research laboratories of
today."

Glee Club Rehearses
First Time at Y. M.C. A.
Tryouts having been conducted
during the past week, the Johns
Hopkins Glee Club, under the direction of Mr. Steinwald, held its
first rehearsal in Levering Hall on
Thursday evening, October 16. According to Bruce Peake, president
of the Musical Club, prospects for
the corning season are very birght.
There has been an especially large
turnout for the Glee Club this year
and the group is of a very promising nature. At the present time the
organization is rehearsing "The
Song of the Jolly Roger," a lively
tune of the sea. The vocalists are
very enthusiastic over this number,
for it is a truly virile piece of music.
Although no definite plans have
been made, the club will probably
start rehearsal on a spiritual number in the near future. Frequent
recitals will be held throughout the
year, and several trips have been
scheduled. The Blue Jay Orchestra
rehearsed on Thursday afternoon
and, according to Bert Clark, the
leader, there are a few positions
still available to candidates.

and Sonny Kneip, have returned to
the University. Several Freshmen
have shown very promising work,
especially Don Kelly, from Friends
School, who was seen with the
Olympics last year, and Millard
Lang, the brother of Johnny Lang,
erstwhile Jay star. The loss of a
goalkeeper will be keenly felt, both
Corner Brownley and Joe Ferrarini
having graduated. Gene Lyons and
Sam Dell will try to fill this vacancy.
The Hopkins team opens the season on March 28 against the Olympics. On April 4 they will meet
Yale; April 11, Swarthmore; the
next week, Virginia. On April 25
they play Mt. \Vashington ; on May
1, Princeton, and May 2, St. Johns;
May 9, Syracuse, and Army on
May 16. • The season will be concluded on May 23 when the Jays
play Maryland.
Last year Hopkins lost only one
league game, finishing in a triple tie
for first place. It is expected that
this year the team will be better
than ever. However, they face a
very hard schedule of ten games.
On May 1 the team travels to
Princeton and the following day
they face St. Johns at home. Only
a super-team can face this with
hopes of victory, but the prospects
of victories are very bright.
Candidates are asked to be
present at practices every Tuesday
and Friday afternoon. The importance of Fall practice cannot be
over-emphasized. Candidates for
Freshman managership are asked to
report to Manager L. A. McNeer at
the field on Tuesdays and Fridays.

The fourth dance to be sponsored
by the Johns Hopkins Cotillion
Board this year is scheduled for
next Saturday, October 25, in
Levering Hall. Bob Iula's Orchestra will furnish the music.

RICES should be lower at the Levering Hall cafeteria than in any
other cafeteria in the city. However, this does not seem to be the
case. Many students find that they receive more for their money in
other places, and hence refuse to patronize the local restaurant. The
cafeteria at Levering Hall is not supposed to make a profit. It is intended that enough be made to pay for the upkeep and a small rent.
Other cafeterias have an overhead which is higher than this rent and
upkeep, and must also make a profit. Something is wrong with the local
cafeteria. Either the management is poor or more money is being
made than Y. M. C. A. originally planned. In either case a change
should take place.
Last year many experiments had to be made. Innovations were
frequent, and profits were few. The problem of a rush at twelve
twenty was met and solved as well as possible. New situations constantly came up. By now the institution should be stabilized. The
period of experimentation should have come to an end. Definite
figures as to how many people eat at each meal are at hand. It should
be relatively easy to determine what profits will be and what prices
should be charged.
We hear the situation is being investigated and that an early
change may be anticipated. If such a decrease does not soon take
place, serious and just criticism will certainly result, and the cafeteria
may expect a lean future.
